words.definition: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
words.etymology: Late 16th century: from Latin 'aberratio(n-)', from the verb 'aberrare', from 'ab-' away + 'errare' to stray.
words.example: The storm was an aberration from the usual weather pattern.

words.definition: To regard with disgust and hatred.
words.etymology: Late Middle English: from Latin 'abhorrere', from 'ab-' away from + 'horrere' to shudder.
words.example: She abhors violence of any kind.

words.definition: The act of renouncing or rejecting something; self-denial.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'abnegatio(n-)' from 'abnegare', from 'ab-' away + 'negare' deny.
words.example: His life of abnegation and austerity was quite admirable.

words.definition: To repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
words.etymology: Early 16th century, from Latin 'abrogat-', 'abrogare', from 'ab-' away, 'rogare' to propose (a law).
words.example: The government decided to abrogate the outdated law.

words.definition: To leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to avoid detection or arrest.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'abscondere' to hide away, from 'abs-' away + 'condere' to stow.
words.example: The thief absconded with the stolen jewels.

words.definition: Difficult to understand; obscure.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'abstrusus', past participle of 'abstrudere' to conceal, from 'ab-' away + 'trudere' to push.
words.example: The professor's lectures were so abstruse that many students gave up.

words.definition: An award or privilege granted as a special honour or as an acknowledgment of merit.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from French, from Provençal 'acolada', based on Latin 'ad-' to + 'collum' neck (referring to the ceremonial embrace conferred by a king when knighting someone).
words.example: She received accolades from critics and fans alike.

words.definition: Angry and bitter (typically of speech or debate).
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from acrimony + -ous.
words.example: Their acrimonious divorce proceedings dragged on for years.

words.definition: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Latin 'acumen' meaning sharpness, from 'acuere' to sharpen.
words.example: His business acumen led the company to success.

words.definition: To warn or reprimand someone firmly.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'admonester', based on Latin 'admonere', from 'ad-' to + 'monere' to warn.
words.example: She admonished him for his rudeness.

words.definition: Excessive admiration or praise.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'adulatio(n-)' from 'adulari' to fawn on.
words.example: The star enjoyed the adulation of his fans.

words.definition: The protection, backing, or support of a particular person or organization.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, via Latin from Greek 'aigis', meaning shield of Zeus.
words.example: The project was developed under the aegis of the university.

words.definition: Friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'affabilis', from 'ad-' to + 'fari' to speak.
words.example: He was an affable and agreeable companion.

words.definition: Having a great deal of money; wealthy.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'affluent-', 'affluere', from 'ad-' to + 'fluere' to flow.
words.example: The affluent neighbourhood was full of mansions and luxury cars.

words.definition: To increase the power, status, or wealth of.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from French 'agrandiss-' (from the verb 'agrandir', based on Latin 'grandis' large).
words.example: The politician used every opportunity to aggrandize his position.

words.definition: Brisk and cheerful readiness.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'alacritas', from 'alacer' lively, eager.
words.example: She accepted the invitation with alacrity.

words.definition: The belief in or practice of selfless concern for the well-being of others.
words.etymology: Mid 19th century, from French 'altruisme', from 'autrui' meaning 'other people'.
words.example: Her altruism was evident in her volunteer work.

words.definition: To combine or unite to form one organization or structure.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from medieval Latin 'amalgamat-', from the verb 'amalgamare', from 'amalgama'.
words.example: The two companies amalgamated to increase their market share.

words.definition: To make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better.
words.etymology: Late 18th century, from Latin 'meliorare', from 'melior' better.
words.example: The reforms were designed to ameliorate the situation.

words.definition: Open and responsive to suggestion; easily persuaded or controlled.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Old French 'amener' bring to, from 'a-' (from Latin 'ad-' to) + 'mener' to lead.
words.example: The patients were amenable to treatment.

words.definition: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Greek 'anakhronismos', from 'ana-' back + 'khronos' time.
words.example: The sword in the modern-day film was an anachronism.

words.definition: Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes.
words.etymology: Early 16th century, from ecclesiastical Latin, 'excommunicated', from Greek 'anathema' meaning 'an offering' or 'something dedicated'.
words.example: Violence was anathema to his beliefs.

words.definition: To append or add as an extra or subordinate part, especially to a document.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'annexer', from Latin 'annectere' to tie or bind.
words.example: The treaty was annexed to the agreement.

words.definition: A deep-seated feeling of aversion.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from French 'antipathie', from Latin 'antipathia', from Greek 'antipatheia', from 'anti-' against + 'pathos' feeling.
words.example: His antipathy towards authority figures was well known.

words.definition: Showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
words.etymology: Mid 18th century, from Greek 'apatheia', from 'apathēs' without feeling, from 'a-' without + 'pathos' emotion.
words.example: The voters were apathetic about the upcoming election.

words.definition: Of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from ecclesiastical Latin 'apocryphus', from Greek 'apokruphos' meaning hidden or secret.
words.example: The apocryphal story spread quickly through the town.

words.definition: A name or title.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French, from Latin 'appellatio(n-)', from 'appellare' meaning to address.
words.example: He earned the appellation of 'the Great' due to his achievements.

words.definition: Approval or praise.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'approbatio(n-)', from 'approbare' to approve.
words.example: The plan won the approbation of all the staff.

words.definition: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'arbitrarius', from 'arbiter' judge, supreme ruler.
words.example: His arbitrary decision left everyone confused.

words.definition: Understood by few; mysterious or secret.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'arcanus' meaning secret, from 'arca' chest.
words.example: The rituals of the cult were arcane and inscrutable.

words.definition: To find (something) out for certain; make sure of.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'acertener', based on Latin 'certus' settled, sure.
words.example: An attempt to ascertain the cause of the accident.

words.definition: Harshness of tone or manner.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'asperite', from Latin 'asperitas', from 'asper' rough.
words.example: He pointed out the flaws with some asperity.

words.definition: Showing great care and perseverance.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'assiduus', from 'assidere' to attend to.
words.example: She was assiduous in her duties, ensuring everything was perfect.

words.definition: Protection granted by a nation to someone who has left their native country as a political refugee.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, via Latin from Greek 'asulon', from 'a-' without + 'sulon' right of seizure.
words.example: The political dissident sought asylum in a neighbouring country.

words.definition: To reduce the force, effect, or value of.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'attenuatus', past participle of 'attenuare' meaning to make thin.
words.example: The drug's effect was attenuated by the consumption of alcohol.

words.definition: Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'audax', from 'audere' meaning to dare.
words.example: Her audacious decision paid off.

words.definition: To make (something) greater by adding to it; increase.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'augmenter', from late Latin 'augmentare', from 'augere' to increase.
words.example: He augmented his income by working overtime.

words.definition: Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'austere', from Latin 'austerus', from Greek 'austēros' severe.
words.example: The austere teacher rarely smiled.

words.definition: Extreme greed for wealth or material gain.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'avarice', from Latin 'avaritia', from 'avarus' greedy.
words.example: His life was driven by avarice.

words.definition: A statement or proposition which is regarded as being established, accepted, or self-evidently true.
words.etymology: Late 15th century, from French 'axiome', or via late Latin from Greek 'axiōma' that which is thought worthy or fit, from 'axios' worthy.
words.example: It is an axiom that supply equals demand.

words.definition: Threatening harm; menacing.
words.etymology: Old English 'bealoful', from 'bealu' evil + 'ful'.
words.example: She gave him a baleful glance.

words.definition: A projecting part of a fortification built at an angle to the line of a wall.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from French, from Italian 'bastire' to build.
words.example: The bastion stood strong against the attacking forces.

words.definition: To fail to give a true notion or impression of (something); disguise or contradict.
words.etymology: Old English 'belēogan' meaning to deceive by lying, from 'be-' about + 'lēogan' to lie.
words.example: His calm manner belied his inner turmoil.

words.definition: Well meaning and kindly.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'benevolent-', from 'bene' well + 'velle' to wish.
words.example: The benevolent stranger offered to pay for the groceries.

words.definition: Gentle and kind.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'benigne', from Latin 'benignus', from 'bene' well + 'genus' born.
words.example: The old man had a benign smile.

words.definition: To leave (a personal estate or one's body) to a person or other beneficiary by a will.
words.etymology: Old English 'becwethan' meaning to declare or give by will.
words.example: He bequeathed his entire estate to his daughter.

words.definition: To obtain or withhold money from (someone) unfairly or by deceit; cheat or defraud.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century (originally denoting a hoax or trick): probably a variant of 'balk'.
words.example: The fraudster bilked investors out of millions.

words.definition: A flattering or pleasing statement or action used to persuade someone gently to do something.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'blandir', from Latin 'blandus' flattering.
words.example: She used all her blandishments to get her way.

words.definition: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'bombace' meaning 'cotton padding', used in an earlier sense of 'pompous speech'.
words.example: His bombastic speech was full of exaggerated claims.

words.definition: A thing that is helpful or beneficial.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old Norse 'bón' prayer.
words.example: The donation was a great boon to the charity.

words.definition: Abrupt or offhand in speech or manner.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from French 'brusque', from Italian 'brusco' meaning 'sour'.
words.example: His brusque manner sometimes offends people.

words.definition: Irritatingly self-assertive.
words.etymology: Early 19th century, from 'bump' + '-tious'.
words.example: His bumptious attitude alienated his colleagues.

words.definition: To polish (something, especially metal) by rubbing.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'burniss-', lengthened stem of 'burnir', based on late Latin 'burinire' to polish.
words.example: He burnished the silver until it shone.

words.definition: A structure of stone or brick built against a wall to strengthen or support it.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'boterace', from 'boter' to strike or butt.
words.example: The cathedral’s walls were supported by massive buttresses.

words.definition: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Greek 'kakophōnia', from 'kakophōnos' meaning 'ill-sounding', from 'kakos' bad + 'phōnē' voice.
words.example: The cacophony of car horns filled the air.

words.definition: Resembling a corpse in being very pale, thin, or bony.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Latin 'cadaver' corpse.
words.example: His cadaverous appearance alarmed his friends.

words.definition: Showing or having an insensitive and cruel disregard for others.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'callosus' meaning hard-skinned.
words.example: His callous disregard for others' feelings was shocking.

words.definition: The making of false and defamatory statements about someone in order to damage their reputation.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'calumnia' meaning 'false statement'.
words.example: He was the victim of calumny from his political opponents.

words.definition: Mutual trust and friendship among people who spend a lot of time together.
words.etymology: Mid 19th century, from French, from 'camarade' meaning comrade.
words.example: The camaraderie among the team members was palpable.

words.definition: The quality of being open and honest in expression; frankness.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'candor' meaning 'whiteness'.
words.example: His candor in discussing the issue was refreshing.

words.definition: Cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from French 'capituler', from medieval Latin 'capitulare', from 'capitulum' chapter (so called because agreements were formally divided into sections).
words.example: The army capitulated after losing the battle.

words.definition: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from French 'capricieux', from Italian 'capriccioso', from 'capriccio' meaning 'sudden start or motion'.
words.example: Her capricious nature made it hard to predict her actions.

words.definition: A picture, description, or imitation of a person in which certain striking characteristics are exaggerated in order to create a comic or grotesque effect.
words.etymology: Mid 18th century, from French, from Italian 'caricatura', from 'caricare' meaning 'to load'.
words.example: The artist's caricature of the politician exaggerated his large nose.

words.definition: Reprimand (someone) severely.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'castigat-', from the verb 'castigare', from 'castus' pure, chaste.
words.example: The teacher castigated the students for their poor performance.

words.definition: A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
words.etymology: Early 20th century, from Greek 'katalusis' meaning dissolution, from 'kataluein' to dissolve.
words.example: The new manager was the catalyst for change in the company.

words.definition: The process of releasing, and thereby providing relief from, strong or repressed emotions.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Greek 'katharsis' meaning purification.
words.example: Crying after the argument was a catharsis for her.

words.definition: Able to burn or corrode organic tissue by chemical action.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'causticus', from Greek 'kaustikos', from 'kaustos' meaning 'combustible'.
words.example: The cleaner contained caustic chemicals.

words.definition: Express severe disapproval of (someone or something), typically in a formal statement.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'censurer', from Latin 'censura' meaning 'judgment or assessment'.
words.example: The senator was censured for his inappropriate remarks.

words.definition: Of the cerebrum of the brain.
words.etymology: Early 19th century, from French 'cérébral', from Latin 'cerebrum' meaning 'brain'.
words.example: His cerebral approach to the problem was impressive.

words.definition: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from French 'chicanerie', from 'chicaner' to quibble.
words.example: The candidate was accused of chicanery during the campaign.

words.definition: Scold or rebuke.
words.etymology: Old English 'cīdan' meaning 'quarrel'.
words.example: The mother chided her child for running into the street.

words.definition: Bad-tempered or irritable.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'colerique', from Latin 'cholē' meaning 'bile', one of the four bodily humours (thought to cause a temper).
words.example: His choleric nature made him difficult to work with.

words.definition: Wary and unwilling to take risks.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'circumspectus', from 'circum-' around + 'specere' to look.
words.example: She was circumspect in her decision to invest in the new company.

words.definition: Find a way around (an obstacle).
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'circumvent-', from 'circumvenire', from 'circum-' around + 'venire' to come.
words.example: He circumvented the security system to gain access to the building.

words.definition: Kept secret or done secretively, especially because illicit.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'clandestinus', from 'clam' secretly.
words.example: Their clandestine meetings were held in a hidden location.

words.definition: Come together to form one mass or whole.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'coalescere', from 'co-' together + 'alescere' grow.
words.example: The two companies coalesced to create a larger organization.

words.definition: (of an argument or case) clear, logical, and convincing.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'cogent-', 'cogere' meaning 'compel'.
words.example: Her cogent argument persuaded the jury.

words.definition: Corresponding in size or degree; in proportion.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from late Latin 'commensuratus', from 'com-' together + 'mensuratus' measured.
words.example: Salary will be commensurate with experience.

words.definition: A collection of concise but detailed information about a particular subject, especially in a book or other publication.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Latin, from 'compendere' meaning 'weigh together'.
words.example: The book is a compendium of facts about the natural world.

words.definition: A feeling of guilt or moral scruple that prevents or follows the doing of something bad.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'compunction', from Latin 'compunctio(n-)', from 'compungere' to prick sharply.
words.example: She had no compunction about lying to get what she wanted.

words.definition: Naturally accompanying or associated.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from late Latin 'concomitant-', from the verb 'concomitari', from 'con-' together with + 'comitari' to accompany.
words.example: She loved travel, with all its concomitant worries.

words.definition: An extensive fire which destroys a great deal of land or property.
words.etymology: Late 15th century, from Latin 'conflagratio(n-)', from 'conflagrare' to blaze together.
words.example: The conflagration spread quickly through the forest.

words.definition: The junction of two rivers, especially rivers of approximately equal width.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from late Latin 'confluentia', from Latin 'confluere' meaning 'flow together'.
words.example: The confluence of the rivers created a powerful current.

words.definition: An opinion or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'conjecturer', from Latin 'conjectura', from 'conicere' meaning 'throw together'.
words.example: Her conjecture about the cause of the problem was based on guesswork.

words.definition: Secretly allow (something considered immoral, illegal, or harmful) to occur.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from French 'conniver', from Latin 'connivere', from 'con-' together + 'nivere' meaning 'to wink'.
words.example: The police were accused of conniving with criminals.

words.definition: An expert judge in matters of taste.
words.etymology: Early 18th century, from French 'connaisseur', from 'connaître' meaning 'know'.
words.example: He was a connoisseur of fine wines.

words.definition: Relating to or denoting people descended from the same ancestor.
words.etymology: Late 17th century, from Latin 'consanguineus' meaning 'of the same blood'.
words.example: The consanguineous nature of the community made it close-knit.

words.definition: Feelings of anxiety or dismay, typically at something unexpected.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'consternatio(n-)', from 'consternare', from 'con-' expressing intensive force + 'sternere' meaning 'lay prostrate'.
words.example: To his consternation, the door was locked.

words.definition: Interpret (a word or action) in a particular way.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'construere' meaning 'build up, pile together'.
words.example: His remarks were construed as an attack on the government.

words.definition: Showing a high degree of skill and flair; complete or perfect.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'consummat-' meaning 'brought to completion', from 'consummare', from 'con-' altogether + 'summa' meaning 'sum total'.
words.example: She was a consummate professional.

words.definition: Causing or likely to cause an argument; controversial.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'contentieux', from Latin 'contentiosus', from 'contentio' meaning 'strife'.
words.example: The contentious issue divided the community.

words.definition: Sharing a common border; touching.
words.etymology: Early 16th century, from Latin 'contiguus' meaning 'touching', from 'contingere' meaning 'be in contact with'.
words.example: The contiguous states share a border.

words.definition: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence; affected by guilt.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French, or from Latin 'contritus', past participle of 'conterere' meaning 'grind down', from 'con-' expressing intensive force + 'terere' meaning 'to rub'.
words.example: She was contrite after causing the accident.

words.definition: (of an atmosphere or event) friendly, lively, and enjoyable.
words.etymology: Late 17th century, from Latin 'convivium' meaning 'a feast', from 'con-' together + 'vivere' to live.
words.example: The wedding reception was a convivial affair.

words.definition: Abundant in supply or quantity.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'copieux' or Latin 'copiosus', from 'copia' meaning 'plenty'.
words.example: She took copious notes during the lecture.

words.definition: Confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding).
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'corroborat-', from 'corroborare', from 'cor-' together + 'roborare' meaning 'to strengthen'.
words.example: The witness corroborated the defendant's alibi.

words.definition: Belief in or acceptance of something as true.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French, from Latin 'credentia', from 'credere' meaning 'to believe'.
words.example: The report gave credence to the rumours.

words.definition: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things.
words.etymology: Early 16th century, from Latin 'credulus' meaning 'easily deceived'.
words.example: The credulous audience believed every word of the scammer's speech.

words.definition: Large or heavy and therefore difficult to carry or use; unwieldy.
words.etymology: Late Middle English (in the sense 'difficult to get through'): from 'cumber' + '-some'.
words.example: The cumbersome package was hard to transport.

words.definition: Greed for money or possessions.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'cupidite', from Latin 'cupiditas', from 'cupidus' meaning 'desirous', from 'cupere' meaning 'to desire'.
words.example: His cupidity led him to embezzle funds.

words.definition: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'cursorius', from 'cursor' meaning 'runner', from 'currere' meaning 'to run'.
words.example: The report was completed in a cursory manner.

words.definition: A scarcity or lack of something.
words.etymology: Middle English, from 'dear' + '-th'.
words.example: There was a dearth of job opportunities in the small town.

words.definition: A sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco.
words.etymology: Early 19th century, from French 'débâcle', from 'débâcler' meaning 'to unbar', from 'des-' meaning 'away' + 'bacler' meaning 'to bar'.
words.example: The dinner party turned into a debacle when the chef quit.

words.definition: Expose the falseness or hollowness of (a myth, idea, or belief).
words.etymology: 1920s, from 'bunk', short for 'bunkum'.
words.example: The journalist debunked the conspiracy theory.

words.definition: Moral or cultural decline as characterized by excessive indulgence in pleasure or luxury.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from French 'décadence', from medieval Latin 'decadentia', from 'decadere' meaning 'to decay'.
words.example: The decadence of the Roman Empire contributed to its fall.

words.definition: Behaviour in keeping with good taste and propriety.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin, neuter of 'decorus' meaning 'seemly'.
words.example: She maintained her decorum throughout the formal dinner.

words.definition: Polite submission and respect.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from French 'déférence', from 'déférer' meaning 'to defer'.
words.example: He addressed her with deference, recognising her authority.

words.definition: Causing harm or damage.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Greek 'dēlētērios' meaning 'noxious'.
words.example: The deleterious effects of smoking are well known.

words.definition: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people rather than by using rational argument.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Greek 'dēmagōgos', from 'dēmos' meaning 'the people' + 'agōgos' meaning 'leading'.
words.example: The demagogue manipulated public fears to gain support.

words.definition: Raise doubts or objections or show reluctance.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'demourer', based on Latin 'demorari' meaning 'to delay'.
words.example: She agreed without demur.

words.definition: Criticize unfairly; disparage.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'denigrat-', from the verb 'denigrare', from 'de-' meaning 'away, completely' + 'niger' meaning 'black'.
words.example: The media denigrated the politician’s reputation.

words.definition: An act of attacking or plundering.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'depraedatio(n-)', from 'depraedari' meaning 'plunder'.
words.example: The depredation of the village by the invaders was swift and brutal.

words.definition: A ruler or other person who holds absolute power, typically one who exercises it in a cruel or oppressive way.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from French 'despote', via medieval Latin from Greek 'despotēs' meaning 'master'.
words.example: The despot ruled with an iron fist.

words.definition: (Especially of fabric) light, delicate, and translucent.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from medieval Latin 'diaphanus', from Greek 'diaphanēs', from 'dia-' meaning 'through' + 'phainein' meaning 'to show'.
words.example: The diaphanous curtains billowed gently in the breeze.

words.definition: Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Greek 'didaktikos', from 'didaskein' meaning 'to teach'.
words.example: The didactic novel aimed to impart moral lessons.

words.definition: Modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'diffident-', from the verb 'diffidere', from 'dis-' meaning 'away' + 'fidere' meaning 'to trust'.
words.example: The diffident student was reluctant to speak in class.

words.definition: Slow to act.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'dilatoire', from Latin 'dilatorius', from 'dilatare' meaning 'defer, postpone'.
words.example: The government’s dilatory response frustrated the public.

words.definition: Extremely or unusually small.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French, from Latin 'diminutivus', from 'diminuere' meaning 'diminish'.
words.example: The diminutive figure seemed out of place among the tall athletes.

words.definition: Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'disparatus', from 'disparare' meaning 'to separate'.
words.example: The two theories are based on disparate assumptions.

words.definition: Conceal one's true motives, feelings, or beliefs.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'dissimuler', based on Latin 'dissimulare' meaning 'to disguise'.
words.example: He dissembled his true intentions with a smile.

words.definition: Disagreement that leads to discord.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'dissension', from Latin 'dissensio(n-)', from 'dissentire' meaning 'to differ in sentiment'.
words.example: The political party was torn apart by internal dissension.

words.definition: Disperse or scatter.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'dissipare' meaning 'scatter'.
words.example: The fog dissipated as the sun rose.

words.definition: Ready to accept control or instruction; submissive.
words.etymology: Late 15th century, from Latin 'docilis', from 'docere' meaning 'teach'.
words.example: The docile puppy quickly learned new commands.

words.definition: Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from late Latin 'dogmaticus', from Greek 'dogmatikos', from 'dogma' meaning 'opinion'.
words.example: The professor's dogmatic approach left no room for debate.

words.definition: Relentlessly severe, stern, or gloomy in manner or appearance.
words.etymology: Late Middle English (in the sense 'obstinate'): probably from Scottish Gaelic 'dur', from Latin 'durus' meaning 'hard'.
words.example: The dour expression on his face revealed his disappointment.

words.definition: Deceitfulness; double-dealing.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French, from late Latin 'duplicitas', from 'duplex' meaning 'double'.
words.example: Her duplicity was uncovered when she was caught lying to both parties.

words.definition: Cheerful and full of energy.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Latin 'ebullient-', from 'ebullire' meaning 'to boil up'.
words.example: Her ebullient personality made her the life of the party.

words.definition: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
words.etymology: Late 17th century, from Greek 'eklektikos', from 'eklegein' meaning 'to pick out'.
words.example: His eclectic taste in music included everything from classical to punk rock.

words.definition: A large, imposing building.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'aedificium', from 'aedificare' meaning 'to build'.
words.example: The cathedral was an impressive edifice.

words.definition: Erase (a mark) from a surface.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from French 'effacer', from 'e-' meaning 'away' + 'face' meaning 'face'.
words.example: The inscription had been effaced by the passage of time.

words.definition: (Of a liquid) giving off bubbles; fizzy.
words.etymology: Early 18th century, from Latin 'effervescere', from 'ex-' meaning 'out, up' + 'fervescere' meaning 'begin to boil'.
words.example: The effervescent drink tickled her throat.

words.definition: The ability to produce a desired or intended result.
words.etymology: Early 16th century, from Latin 'efficacia', from 'efficax' meaning 'efficacious'.
words.example: The efficacy of the treatment was confirmed by the studies.

words.definition: Insolent or impertinent behaviour.
words.etymology: Late 17th century, from French 'effronterie', based on late Latin 'effrons' meaning 'shameless'.
words.example: The student's effrontery in speaking back to the teacher was shocking.

words.definition: Outstandingly bad; shocking.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'egregius' meaning 'standing out from the flock'.
words.example: The company's egregious disregard for the environment led to public outrage.

words.definition: Evoke or draw out (a reaction, answer, or fact) from someone.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'elicere', from 'e-' meaning 'out' + 'lacere' meaning 'entice'.
words.example: The comedian's jokes elicited laughter from the audience.

words.definition: Make (something) clear; explain.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from late Latin 'elucidat-', from 'elucidare', from 'e-' meaning 'out' + 'lucidus' meaning 'lucid'.
words.example: The professor elucidated the complex theory with several examples.

words.definition: Abnormally thin or weak, especially because of illness or a lack of food.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'emaciatus', from the verb 'emaciare', from 'e-' meaning 'out' + 'macies' meaning 'leanness'.
words.example: The emaciated refugees were given food and shelter.

words.definition: Make corrections and improvements to (a text).
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'emendare', from 'e-' meaning 'out' + 'mendum' meaning 'fault'.
words.example: The editor emended the manuscript before publication.

words.definition: (Of a person) famous and respected within a particular sphere or profession.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'eminent-', from 'eminere' meaning 'stand out'.
words.example: The eminent scientist was awarded a Nobel Prize.

words.definition: Having the quality of softening or soothing the skin.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'emollient-', from the verb 'emollire', from 'e-' meaning 'out' + 'mollis' meaning 'soft'.
words.example: The emollient lotion relieved her dry skin.

words.definition: Based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'empiricus', from Greek 'empeirikos', from 'empeiria' meaning 'experience'.
words.example: The empirical data supported the scientist's hypothesis.

words.definition: Cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'enervat-', from the verb 'enervare', from 'e-' meaning 'out of' + 'nervus' meaning 'sinew'.
words.example: The heat enervated the workers, making it hard to continue.

words.definition: Give the right to vote to.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'enfranchir', from 'en-' meaning 'in' + 'franc' meaning 'free'.
words.example: The movement sought to enfranchise all citizens, regardless of gender.

words.definition: Cause or give rise to (a feeling, situation, or condition).
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'engendrer', from Latin 'ingenerare', from 'in-' meaning 'in' + 'generare' meaning 'beget'.
words.example: The controversial decision engendered a debate among the community.

words.definition: A person or thing that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, via Latin from Greek 'ainigma', from 'ainissesthai' meaning 'speak allusively'.
words.example: The artist was an enigma, known for his cryptic messages.

words.definition: The state or feeling of being actively opposed or hostile to someone or something.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French 'enemistie', based on Latin 'inimicus'.
words.example: The longstanding enmity between the two nations was hard to overcome.

words.definition: A feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from a lack of occupation or excitement.
words.etymology: Mid 18th century, from French, from Latin 'inodiare' meaning 'to make loathsome'.
words.example: The endless meetings filled him with ennui.

words.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Greek 'ephemeros' meaning 'lasting only a day'.
words.example: The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral.

words.definition: Relating to or denoting the writing of letters or literary works in the form of letters.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from French 'épistolaire', from Latin 'epistolaris', from 'epistola' meaning 'letter'.
words.example: The novel was written in an epistolary format.

words.definition: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'aequanimitas', from 'aequus' meaning 'equal' + 'animus' meaning 'mind'.
words.example: She handled the stressful situation with remarkable equanimity.

words.definition: Use ambiguous language so as to conceal the truth or avoid committing oneself.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from late Latin 'aequivocat-' meaning 'called by the same name'.
words.example: The politician equivocated when asked about the scandal.

words.definition: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'eruditus', from 'erudire' meaning 'instruct'.
words.example: The professor's erudite lecture impressed the students.

words.definition: Deliberately avoid using; abstain from.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'eschiver', of Germanic origin; related to 'shun'.
words.example: He eschewed violence in all its forms.

words.definition: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Greek 'esōterikos', from 'esōterō' meaning 'within', from 'eis' meaning 'into'.
words.example: The esoteric philosophy was difficult for outsiders to grasp.

words.definition: Adopt or support (a cause, belief, or way of life).
words.etymology: Late Middle English (in the sense 'marry'): from Old French 'espouser', from Latin 'sponsare', from 'spondere' meaning 'betroth'.
words.example: The senator espoused the idea of reform.

words.definition: Extremely delicate and light in a way that seems too perfect for this world.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Greek 'aitherios', from 'aither' meaning 'ether'.
words.example: The ballerina's ethereal movements captivated the audience.

words.definition: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, especially a tribute to someone who has just died.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from medieval Latin 'eulogium', from Greek 'eulogia' meaning 'praise'.
words.example: His eulogy at the funeral was heartfelt.

words.definition: A mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered to be too harsh or blunt when referring to something unpleasant or embarrassing.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Greek 'euphemismos', from 'euphēmizein' meaning 'use auspicious words', from 'eu-' meaning 'well' + 'phēmē' meaning 'speaking'.
words.example: The company used 'downsizing' as a euphemism for layoffs.

words.definition: Soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.
words.etymology: Early 18th century, from Latin 'evanescent-', from the verb 'evanescere', from 'e-' meaning 'out of' + 'vanescere' meaning 'vanish'.
words.example: The evanescent rainbow disappeared as quickly as it appeared.

words.definition: Reveal the presence of (a quality or feeling); indicate.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Latin 'evincere', from 'e-' meaning 'out' + 'vincere' meaning 'overcome'.
words.example: His comments evinced a genuine interest in the topic.

words.definition: Make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'exacerbat-', from the verb 'exacerbare', from 'ex-' meaning 'thoroughly' + 'acerbus' meaning 'harsh, bitter'.
words.example: His refusal to apologize only exacerbated the tension.

words.definition: Show or declare that (someone) is not guilty of wrongdoing.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from medieval Latin 'exculpat-', from 'exculpare', from 'ex-' meaning 'out' + 'culpa' meaning 'blame'.
words.example: The evidence exculpated the defendant from any wrongdoing.

words.definition: Serving as a desirable model; representing the best of its kind.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from late Latin 'exemplaris', from Latin 'exemplum' meaning 'example'.
words.example: Her exemplary work ethic set a standard for others.

words.definition: Pressing; demanding.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'exigent-', from 'exigere', from 'ex-' meaning 'out' + 'agere' meaning 'drive'.
words.example: The exigent demands of the job were overwhelming.

words.definition: (Especially of an official body) absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing, especially after due consideration of the case.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'exonerat-', from the verb 'exonerare', from 'ex-' meaning 'from' + 'onus' meaning 'a burden'.
words.example: The DNA evidence exonerated him from the crime.

words.definition: (Of a price or amount charged) unreasonably high.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'exorbitant-', from 'exorbitare', from 'ex-' meaning 'out from' + 'orbita' meaning 'track'.
words.example: The exorbitant price of the meal shocked the diners.

words.definition: (Of an action) convenient and practical, although possibly improper or immoral.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'expedient-', from the verb 'expedire', from 'ex-' meaning 'out' + 'pes' meaning 'foot'.
words.example: The mayor's decision to approve the project was politically expedient.

words.definition: Atone for (guilt or sin).
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'expiat-', from the verb 'expiare', from 'ex-' meaning 'out' + 'piare' meaning 'appease'.
words.example: He tried to expiate his sins by donating to charity.

words.definition: To erase or remove completely; to obliterate or delete.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'expungere', meaning to mark for deletion (from 'ex-' meaning out and 'pungere' meaning to prick).
words.example: The criminal record was expunged after the charges were dropped.

words.definition: (Especially of a document) still in existence; surviving.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'exstant-', from the verb 'exstare', from 'ex-' meaning 'out' + 'stare' meaning 'to stand'.
words.example: The only extant copy of the manuscript was found in a library.

words.definition: Spoken or done without preparation.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from late Latin 'extemporaneus', from 'ex tempore' meaning 'out of the time'.
words.example: His extemporaneous speech impressed the audience.

words.definition: Praise enthusiastically.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'extollere', from 'ex-' meaning 'out, upward' + 'tollere' meaning 'raise'.
words.example: The mayor extolled the volunteers for their hard work.

words.definition: Irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'extraneus' meaning 'external, strange', from 'extra' meaning 'outside'.
words.example: The report was full of extraneous information.

words.definition: Extend the application of (a method or conclusion) to an unknown situation by assuming that existing trends will continue or similar methods will be applicable.
words.etymology: Early 19th century, from 'extra-' meaning 'outside' + a shortened form of 'interpolate'.
words.example: The scientist extrapolated future trends based on the data collected.

words.definition: Free (someone or something) from a constraint or difficulty.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'extricat-', from the verb 'extricare', from 'ex-' meaning 'out' + 'tricae' meaning 'perplexities'.
words.example: He tried to extricate himself from the awkward situation.

words.definition: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humour; flippant.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from French 'facétieux', from 'facétie' meaning 'a joke', from Latin 'facetia' meaning 'jest'.
words.example: His facetious remarks during the meeting were not appreciated.

words.definition: Based on a mistaken belief.
words.etymology: Early 16th century, from Latin 'fallaciosus', from 'fallacia' meaning 'deceit', from 'fallax' meaning 'deceptive'.
words.example: The argument was based on fallacious reasoning.

words.definition: Silly and pointless.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'fatuus' meaning 'foolish'.
words.example: His fatuous comments only served to annoy everyone.

words.definition: Producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; fertile.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from French 'fécond', from Latin 'fecundus' meaning 'fruitful'.
words.example: The fecund soil produced a bountiful harvest.

words.definition: Well chosen or suited to the circumstances.
words.etymology: Late 18th century, from Latin 'felicitas' meaning 'happiness'.
words.example: Her felicitous remarks cheered everyone up.

words.definition: (Especially of an animal) in a wild state, especially after escape from captivity or domestication.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'ferus' meaning 'wild'.
words.example: The feral cat prowled through the alleyways.

words.definition: Having or displaying a passionate intensity.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French, from Latin 'fervent-', from 'fervere' meaning 'to boil'.
words.example: His fervent support for the cause was evident.

words.definition: Smelling extremely unpleasant.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'fetidus', from 'fetere' meaning 'to stink'.
words.example: The fetid air in the sewer made it hard to breathe.

words.definition: (Of something considered wrong or immoral) conspicuously or obviously offensive.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'flagrant-' meaning 'blazing', from 'flagrare' meaning 'to blaze'.
words.example: His flagrant disregard for the rules got him into trouble.

words.definition: Having a red or flushed complexion.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'floridus', from 'flos' meaning 'flower'.
words.example: Her florid face betrayed her embarrassment.

words.definition: To confuse or perplex someone greatly; to bewilder.
words.etymology: Mid 19th century, of unknown origin; perhaps related to the dialect word 'flummock', meaning to make untidy.
words.example: The complicated instructions flummoxed everyone who tried to assemble the furniture.

words.definition: A minor weakness or eccentricity in someone's character.
words.etymology: Late 16th century (as an adjective in the sense 'feeble'): from obsolete French, in Old French 'fieble', from Latin 'flebilis' meaning 'lamentable'.
words.example: His only foible was his love for sweets.

words.definition: Patient self-control; restraint and tolerance.
words.etymology: Middle English (in the sense 'endurance, tolerance'): from the verb 'forbear', from Old English 'forberan', from 'for-' meaning 'away, off' + 'beran' meaning 'to bear'.
words.example: The teacher showed remarkable forbearance in dealing with the unruly class.

words.definition: Courage in pain or adversity.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'fortitudo', from 'fortis' meaning 'strong'.
words.example: She showed great fortitude in the face of adversity.

words.definition: Happening by a lucky chance; fortunate.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'fortuitus', from 'fors' meaning 'chance'.
words.example: The fortuitous meeting led to a successful partnership.

words.definition: (Typically of children) irritable and quarrelsome.
words.etymology: Early 18th century, from 'fraction', from Latin 'fractio', from 'frangere' meaning 'to break'.
words.example: The fractious children were difficult to control.

words.definition: Fast and energetic in a rather wild and uncontrolled way.
words.etymology: Late 19th century, from Old French 'frénétique', via Latin from Greek 'phrenitikos', from 'phrenitis' meaning 'delirium'.
words.example: The frenetic pace of the city life was overwhelming.

words.definition: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'furtivus', from 'furtum' meaning 'theft'.
words.example: The furtive glance he gave her aroused suspicion.

words.definition: Obtrusively bright and showy; lurid.
words.etymology: Early 16th century, of unknown origin.
words.example: The garish neon signs lit up the night.

words.definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'garrulus', from 'garrire' meaning 'to chatter'.
words.example: The garrulous old man held up the queue with his endless stories.

words.definition: Friendly and cheerful.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century (in the sense 'pleasantly mild and warm'): from Latin 'genialis', from 'genius' meaning 'attendant spirit present from one's birth'.
words.example: Her genial personality made her popular at work.

words.definition: Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Latin 'grandiloquent-', from 'grandis' meaning 'grand' + 'loqui' meaning 'to speak'.
words.example: His grandiloquent speech failed to impress the audience.

words.definition: (Of a person) fond of company; sociable.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from Latin 'gregarius', from 'grex, greg-' meaning 'a flock'.
words.example: The gregarious host made everyone feel at ease.

words.definition: Sly or cunning intelligence.
words.etymology: Middle English, from Old French, of Germanic origin; related to 'wile'.
words.example: She used her guile to escape the trap.

words.definition: (Of a phrase or idea) lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.
words.etymology: Mid 18th century: from 'hackney' meaning 'used for hire'.
words.example: His speech was full of hackneyed clichés.

words.definition: (Especially of a person) unfortunate.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old Norse 'hap' meaning 'good fortune'.
words.example: The hapless travellers were stranded at the airport for hours.

words.definition: A lengthy and aggressive speech.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'harangue', of Germanic origin.
words.example: The politician's harangue was aimed at stirring up emotions.

words.definition: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Greek 'hēgemonia', from 'hēgemōn' meaning 'leader'.
words.example: The country's economic hegemony allowed it to exert influence over its neighbours.

words.definition: (Of a person or wrongful act, especially a crime) utterly odious or wicked.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'haineus', from 'haine' meaning 'hatred'.
words.example: The heinous crime shocked the entire nation.

words.definition: Diverse in character or content.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from medieval Latin 'heterogeneus', from Greek 'heterogenēs', from 'heteros' meaning 'other' + 'genos' meaning 'a kind'.
words.example: The heterogeneous group included people from all walks of life.

words.definition: A pause or gap in a sequence, series, or process.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin, literally 'gaping'.
words.example: The band took a year-long hiatus after their tour.

words.definition: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from late Latin 'histrionicus', from Latin 'histrio' meaning 'actor'.
words.example: Her histrionic outburst made everyone uncomfortable.

words.definition: A person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century (sense 2): via medieval Latin from ecclesiastical Greek 'eikonoklastēs', from 'eikōn' meaning 'likeness' + 'klan' meaning 'to break'.
words.example: The iconoclast challenged the traditional views of the church.

words.definition: Relating to idiosyncrasy; peculiar or individual.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Greek 'idiosunkratia', from 'idios' meaning 'own, private' + 'sun-' meaning 'with' + 'krasis' meaning 'mixture'.
words.example: His idiosyncratic behaviour made him stand out from the crowd.

words.definition: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from French 'ignominieux', or from Latin 'ignominiosus', from 'ignominia'.
words.example: The ignominious defeat was a blow to the team's morale.

words.definition: Forbidden by law, rules, or custom.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from French 'illicite', from Latin 'illicitus', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'licitus' meaning 'lawful'.
words.example: The police cracked down on the illicit trade in endangered species.

words.definition: Having little or no money.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from 'im-' meaning 'not' + 'pecunious', from Latin 'pecuniosus' meaning 'wealthy'.
words.example: The impecunious student struggled to pay rent.

words.definition: Of vital importance; crucial.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from late Latin 'imperativus', from Latin 'imperare' meaning 'to command'.
words.example: It is imperative that you submit your application by the deadline.

words.definition: Assuming power or authority without justification; arrogant and domineering.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'imperiosus', from 'imperium' meaning 'command, authority, empire'.
words.example: Her imperious tone made everyone feel uncomfortable.

words.definition: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'impetueux', from late Latin 'impetuosus', from 'impetus'.
words.example: His impetuous decision to quit his job surprised everyone.

words.definition: Have an effect or impact, especially a negative one.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'impingere', from 'in-' meaning 'into' + 'pangere' meaning 'fix, drive'.
words.example: The new regulations impinged on the company's ability to operate freely.

words.definition: Unable to be appeased or placated.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'implacabilis', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'placabilis'.
words.example: His implacable hatred for his rival was well known.

words.definition: Ask (someone) pressingly and persistently for or to do something.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'importunus', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'portunus' meaning 'fitting, opportune'.
words.example: The salesman importuned me to buy the product even after I said no.

words.definition: Represent (something, especially something undesirable) as being done, caused, or possessed by someone; attribute.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'imputer', from Latin 'imputare', from 'in-' meaning 'in, towards' + 'putare' meaning 'to settle (an account)'.
words.example: The crimes were imputed to the young man, though he was innocent.

words.definition: Silly; stupid.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'inanis' meaning 'empty, vain'.
words.example: Her inane comments during the meeting irritated everyone.

words.definition: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from Latin 'inchoatus', past participle of 'inchoare' meaning 'to begin'.
words.example: His inchoate ideas lacked focus and clarity.

words.definition: (Of a person or mental process) intelligently analytical and clear-thinking.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from late Latin 'incisivus', from Latin 'incis-', from 'incidere' meaning 'to cut into'.
words.example: Her incisive remarks cut through the confusion and got to the heart of the issue.

words.definition: (Of a person or their tendencies) not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French, from Latin 'incorrigibilis', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'corrigere' meaning 'to correct'.
words.example: His incorrigible habit of arriving late caused frustration at work.

words.definition: (Of a person or their efforts) persisting tirelessly.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'indefatigabilis', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'defatigare' meaning 'wear out'.
words.example: The indefatigable worker never took a day off.

words.definition: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
words.etymology: Mid 17th century, from late Latin 'indolent-', from in-' meaning 'not' + 'dolere' meaning 'to suffer or give pain'.
words.example: The indolent man spent his days lying on the couch.

words.definition: Impossible to subdue or defeat.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'indomitabilis', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'domitare' meaning 'to tame'.
words.example: Her indomitable spirit kept her going even in the face of adversity.

words.definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Old French 'ineffable', from Latin 'ineffabilis', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'effabilis' meaning 'able to be expressed'.
words.example: The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.

words.definition: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
words.etymology: Early 17th century, from Latin 'ineptus', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'aptus' meaning 'fitted'.
words.example: His inept handling of the situation made things worse.

words.definition: Impossible to stop or prevent.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century, from French 'inexorable', from Latin 'inexorabilis', from 'in-' meaning 'not' + 'exorabilis' meaning 'to be moved by entreaty'.
words.example: The inexorable march of time affects us all.

words.definition: (Of a person or action) innocent and unsuspecting.
words.etymology: Late 16th century, from Latin 'ingenuus' meaning 'of noble birth', from 'in-' meaning 'in' + 'gignere' meaning 'to beget'.
words.example: Her ingenuous nature made her easy to trust.

words.definition: Tending to obstruct or harm.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from late Latin 'inimicalis', from Latin 'inimicus'.
words.example: The inimical weather conditions made it difficult to continue the journey.

words.definition: Inborn; natural.
words.etymology: Late Middle English, from Latin 'innatus', from 'in-' meaning 'into' + 'nasci' meaning 'to be born'.
words.example: Her innate sense of justice guided her actions.
